{{chembox | Verifiedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 470619942 | Name = Uranium pentafluoride | ImageFile = beta-UF5.png | ImageCaption = β form | OtherNames = | Section1 = {{Chembox Identifiers | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|changed|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 75545 | InChI = 1/5FH.U/h5*1H;/q;;;;;+2/p-5 | InChIKey = YKLDBRIIJYAXGS-AACRGIKGAA | SMILES = [U+5].[F-].[F-].[F-].[F-].[F-] | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|changed|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/5FH.U/h5*1H;/q;;;;; 5/p-5 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|changed|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = JNVYCANIFQDNST-UHFFFAOYSA-I | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|changed|??}} | CASNo = 13775-07-0 }} | Section2 = {{Chembox Properties | Formula = UF<sub>5</sub> | MolarMass =333.02 g/mol | Density = | Solvent = | SolubleOther = | MeltingPt = | BoilingPt = }} }} '''Uranium pentafluoride''' is the [[inorganic compound]] with the chemical formula UF<sub>5</sub>. It is a pale yellow paramagnetic solid. The compound has attracted interest because it is related to [[uranium hexafluoride]], which is widely used to produce uranium fuel. It crystallizes in two [[polymorphism (materials science)|polymorphs]], called α- and β-UF<sub>5</sub>.
==Synthesis and structure== It can be produced by reduction of the hexafluoride with [[carbon monoxide]] at elevated temperatures.<ref>Gordon W. Halstead, P. Gary Eller "Uranium(V) Fluorides and Alkoxides" Inorganic Syntheses 1982, volume 21, 162. {{DOI|10.1002/9780470132524.ch35}}</ref> : 2 UF<sub>6</sub> + CO → 2 UF<sub>5</sub> + COF<sub>2</sub> Other reducing agents have been examined.<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Inorganica Chimica Acta | year = 1979 | volume = 37 | issue = 2 | pages = 129–133 | title = Crystal structures of α-UF<sub>5</sub> and U<sub>2</sub>F<sub>9</sub> and spectral characterization of U<sub>2</sub>F<sub>9</sub> | author = Eller, P. G. | author2 = Larson, A. C. | author3 = Peterson, J. R. | author4 = Ensor, D. D. | author5 = Young, J. P. | doi = 10.1016/S0020-1693(00)95530-0 }}</ref>
The α form is a linear [[coordination polymer]] consisting of chains of octahedral uranium centers in which one of the five fluoride anion forms a [[bridging ligand|bridge]] to the next uranium atom.<ref name="howard1982">{{cite journal | journal = [[Journal of Solid State Chemistry]] | year = 1982 | volume = 45 | issue = 3 | pages = 396–398 | title = Crystallographic parameters in α-UF<sub>5</sub> and U<sub>2</sub>F<sub>9</sub> by multiphase refinement of high-resolution neutron powder data | author = Howard, C. J. | author2 = Taylor, J. C. | author3 = Waugh, A. B. | doi = 10.1016/0022-4596(82)90185-2|bibcode = 1982JSSCh..45..396H }}</ref> The structure is reminiscent of that for [[vanadium pentafluoride]].
In β form, the uranium centers adopt a [[square antiprism]]atic [[crystal structure|structure]].<ref>{{cite journal | journal = [[Journal of Solid State Chemistry]] | year = 1980 | volume = 35 | issue = 2 | pages = 137–147 | title = Neutron diffraction study of β-uranium pentafluoride between 77 and 403 K | author = Taylor, J. C. | author2 = Waugh, A. B. | doi = 10.1016/0022-4596(80)90485-5 |bibcode = 1980JSSCh..35..137T }}</ref> The β polymorph gradually converts to α at 130 °C.<ref name="howard1982"/><!-- "An α-UF<sub>5</sub>/U<sub>2</sub>F<sub>9</sub> mixture was prepared by heating a β-UF<sub>5</sub> sample from a previous study (5) at 180°C until there was no further change (in 24 hr) in the diffraction pattern." --> <!-- howard1982 cites eller1979 and confirms Eller's Xray to a slightly higher resolution using neutron. howard gives some parameters but Eller might have more structure data to make a nice diagram -->
==Monomeric UF<sub>5</sub>== Of theoretical interest, molecular UF<sub>5</sub> can be generated as a transient [[monomer]] by UV-[[photolysis]] of [[uranium hexafluoride]]. It is thought to adopt a [[square pyramidal]] geometry.<ref>{{cite journal |title= Structure and Bond Nature of the UF<sub>5</sub> Monomer |author= Onoe, J. |author2= Nakamatsu, H. |author3= Mukoyama, T. |author4= Sekine, R. |author5= Adachi, H. |author6= Takeuchi, K. |journal= Inorg. Chem. |year= 1997 |volume= 36 |issue= 9 |pages= 1934–1938 |doi= 10.1021/ic961237s }}</ref> [[File:UF5_monomer.png|thumb|none|180px|Structure of molecular UF<sub>5</sub>.]]

'''Urpek''' is a village in [[Amangeldi District]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geonames.de/coukz-sub.html|title=geonames - Kazakh subdivisions|publisher=|accessdate=18 February 2016}}</ref> of [[Kostanay Region]], northern [[Kazakhstan]].
==Geoglyph==
The Turgay triradial swastika, one of a number of [[Neolithic]] earth constructions known to archaeologists as [[Steppe Geoglyphs]], is at {{Coord|50.102778|N|65.360833|E|type:landmark|display=inline}}, only about half a mile east of Urpek.

The '''wey''' or '''weight''' ([[Old English]]: {{lang|ang|ƿæᵹe}}, ''waege'', <small>{{abbr|lit.|literally}}</small> "weight")<ref>[http://www.unc.edu/~rowlett/units/dictW.html How Many? A Dictionary of Units of Measurement: W]</ref> was an [[English units|English unit]] of [[units of weight|weight]]<!--not mass--> and dry [[volume]] by at least {{sc|ad}} 900, when it begins to be mentioned in surviving legal codes. __NOTOC__ ==Weight== A [[Weights and Measures Acts of the United Kingdom|statute]] of [[Edgar the Peaceful]] set a [[price floor]] on wool by threatening both the seller and purchaser who agreed to trade a '''wool wey''' for less than 120 [[penny (English coin)|pence]]{{refn|[[2 Edgar c. 8]]<ref>{{ Citation |last=Thorpe |first=Benjamin |author-link=Benjamin Thorpe | title=Ancient Laws and Institutes of England; Comprising Laws enacted under the Anglo-Saxon Kings from Æthelbirht to Cnut, With<!--sic--> an English Translation of the Saxon; The<!--sic--> Laws called Edward the Confessor's; The<!--sic--> Laws of William the Conqueror, and those ascribed to Henry the First: Also,<!--sic--> Monumenta Ecclesiastica Anglicana, From<!--sic--> the Seventh to the Tenth Century; And<!--sic--> the Ancient Latin Version of the Anglo-Saxon Laws. With<!--sic--> a Compendious Glossary, &c. | publisher=Commissioners of the Public Records of the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Kingdom]] |date=1840 |contribution=The Laws of King Edgar |contribution-url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QIdCAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA113 |location=London |p=113}}. {{ang icon}} & {{la icon}} & {{en icon}}</ref>}} (i.e., ½ [[Tower pound|pound]] of [[sterling silver]] per wey), but the wey itself varied over time and by location. The wey was standardized as 14 [[stone (unit)|stone]] of 12½ [[merchants' pounds]] each (175 lbs. or around 76.5 kg)<!--More detailed figure inappropriate for pre-20th century--> by the time of the [[Assize of Weights and Measures]] {{circa|lk=no|1300}}. This wey was applied to [[lead]], [[soap]], and [[cheese]] as well as wool. 2 wey made a [[sack (unit)|sack]], 12 a [[load (unit)|load]], and 24 a [[last (unit)|last]].<ref>The [[Assize of Weights and Measures]]. {{circa|lk=no|1300}}.</ref>
The '''wool wey''' was later figured as 2 [[hundredweight]] of 8 [[stone (unit)|stone]] of 14 [[avoirdupois pound]]s each (224 lbs. or about 101.7 kg).<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = Encyclopaedia of Scientific Units, Weights and Measures. Their SI Equivalences and Origins.|last = Cardarelli| first=F. |publisher = Springer|year = 2003|isbn = 978-1-4471-1122-1|location = London|pages = 49}}</ref>
The '''Suffolk wey''' was 356 [[avoirdupois]] [[Pound (mass)|pound]]s (around 161.5 kg).<!--More detailed figure inappropriate for pre-20th century--> It was used as a measure for [[butter]] and [[cheese]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Encyclopaedia of Scientific Units, Weights and Measures. Their SI Equivalences and Origins.|last = Cardarelli|first = F.|publisher = Springer|year = 2003|isbn = 978-1-4471-1122-1|location = London|pages = 46}}</ref>
==Volume== As a measure of volume for dry commodities, it denoted roughly 40 [[bushel]]s or 320 [[gallon]]s.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Encyclopaedia of Scientific Units, Weights and Measures. Their SI Equivalences and Origins.|last = Cardarelli|first = F.|publisher = Springer|year = 2003|isbn = 978-1-4471-1122-1|location = London|pages = 23}}</ref>
